title: Macclesfield Canal Walking Route

images.title: Peter Fuller / Top Locks, Marple, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Top Locks, Marple Top Lock (lock 16) Marple is at the junction of the Macclesfield and Peak Forest Canals. The flight of 16 locks with an average drop of almost 4 metres each are some of the deepest in the country. The canal operated without locks for many years a ropeway taken goods down roughly where the canal towpath is today.

images.title: David Kitching / Adlington Basin, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Adlington Basin. The former Adlington Colliery Basin on the Macclesfield Canal is now a thriving marina with nearby cafe and restaurant.

images.title: Roger  Kidd / Bosley Locks 10 and 11, Macclesfield Canal, Cheshire, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bosley Locks 10 and 11, Macclesfield Canal, Cheshire Lock 10 is viewed across the pound from Lock 11.

images.title: Maurice Pullin [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Below Bosley Locks. The bottom lock can just be seen to the left. The transmitter on Sutton Common (or Croker Hill) is over 3km away.

images.title: Jerry Evans / Bridges over the Macclesfield Canal, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bridges over the Canal. This fine sequence of four stone bridges crosses the Macclesfield Canal on the approach to Buglawton.

images.title: Galatas / Cruising the Macclesfield canal, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cruising along the canal. Entering Red Bull basin having just passed over the Trent and Mersey canal via the aqueduct.

images.title: Roger  Kidd / Evening Reflections on the Macclesfield Canal, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Evening Reflections on the canal approaching Lyme Green, south of Macclesfield. Taken on a calm summer's evening at around six o'clock (BST).

images.title: michael ely / Macclesfield Canal, Hurdsfield, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Hurdsfield.  Looking south from near where the canal goes under Rainow Road.

description: Follow the towpath of the Macclesfield Canal from Marple to Kidsgrove on this waterside walk in Cheshire. Along the way there's lots of interesting lock structures, old bridges, pretty villages, nice pubs and great views of the surrounding Cheshire countryside. The 27 mile canal runs from Marple in Greater Manchester to Kidsgrove in Staffordshire, where it links with the Trent and Mersey Canal. You start of at Marple Canal Locks near to Marple train station. It's a wonderful start to the walk with the fascinating flight of sixteen locks a truly impressive sight. The canal then heads south through the town before branching off to the south west while the adjacent Peak Forest Canal branches off to the south east towards Disley . The canal continues south towards Middlewood and Bollington , before entering Macclesfield itself. After passing through the eastern edge of the town you head out into the countryside again, passing Bosley Locks before coming to Congleton . The Bosley locks are one of the highlights of the route with an impressive flight of twelve canal locks. The final section runs from Congleton to Kidsgrove where the canal links with the Trent and Mersey Canal . The canal is one section of the Cheshire Ring Canal Walk which follows six historic canals through Cheshire, Greater Manchester and Staffordshire. Along the route of the canal there's plenty of opportunities to make short detours and visit some of the area's attractions. For example, around Congleton you can visit the lovely Astbury Mere Country Park and enjoy a waterside walk around the pretty lake. Around Bosley you will find Bosley Reservoir and the climb to Bosley Cloud . Also of interest is the Middlewood Way . The cycling and walking trail runs parallel to the canal from Macclesfield to Marple.
